Today I'm going to give you my review of the 2016 film Hell or High Water. This movie is about a couple of brothers robbing banks to raise money that they owe to a bank. I don't want to tell you why they owe money exactly, because I feel like the story is better off if you find out while watching it, like I did. This movie is honestly my favorite that I've seen this year and today I'm going to tell you guys why this movie is such a classic.

The biggest thing that stuck out to me was the performances of all the actors/actresses in this film, so I'll just go through the list. First off, Chris Pine does an absolutely amazing job in this movie, even though he was great in Star Trek and pretty good in this years Finest Hours, I would say this is the best performance he has given this year, and maybe even the best in his career. One thing I really loved about this performance was the accent that Chris Pine used in this movie, it was very very believable. He also brings a dark and realistic tone to this movie that really sets the tone for this movie and drives the story to be more believable and more relatable. Now Ben Foster in this movie really is unbelievable in this movie, he really embodies this role, while I was watching the movie I couldn't even tell that it was Ben Foster, he does a great job in every way, all in all it was a perfect performance, and I really hope to see him get at least an Oscar nomination for best supporting actor. Now another actor that I firmly believe should be nominated for a best supporting role was Jeff Bridges, who plays this sheriff who is on the verge of retirement and this is his last rodeo, he spends most the movie trying to track down the two criminal brothers. He adds some comedy to this film that fits in perfect, there is not too many jokes and they all seem to hit at perfect times. Jeff Bridges just like Chris Pine gives a great accent that is very believable and feels real. The chemistry between him and Gil Birmingham was perfect, their dialog felt so real it left me wanting to see more of them two together. At the end of the day the performances of this movie were amazing everyone in this film does an absolutely incredible job!

Another thing I really loved in this movie was the music, it really fit so perfectly with the film. The score has kind of a western music theme to it, and it fits so well. The music was so subtle and it just makes you feel more connected with the world, just like every musical score should do.

I also believe that David Mackenzie did a great job directing the movie, every shot felt so real and it felt like it really fit with the tone of this film. David Mackenzie is really a great up and coming directer and I'm excited to see what he does next.
Hell or High Water goes through the motions of a gritty thriller while serving up thought-provoking, ethically complex modern-day questions about those motions, all with a strong emotional center.

All of the actors shine. Chris Pine is not only a beautiful man, but his acting through the years has evolved into something really magnificent. Jeff Bridges is right there with him, and even though he has the more complicated character, this takes nothing away from Pine. Ben Foster plays Pine's brother and his maniacal type of role suits him perfectly. This movie is as rich with its acting as it is with its score and picture. Definitely worth the viewing.

Captures the dire circumstances of boom towns gone bust, when "country" devolves into lost hopes and dreams, turning good men to desperation.  But if that's the background, the rest is a phony pointless plot... not a plot that shows you the pointlessness of it all, mind you, but a pointless story filled with irrational violence.

2008 market crash brought one of the major crisis in the real state market. The so called bubble, make home owners unaware of the major treat of banks taking advantage of their costumers and scamming to the point of foreclosure. Is hard to say how many families were hurt by this, but the idea of someone taking the law in their own hands is another story.

Toby and Tanner Howard brothers living in a rural town in Texas, are holding a big plan to rob several branches of Texas Midland Banks in the early morning. Toby (Chris Pine) a divorced father and Tanner (Ben Forster) an ex-con mother passed away recently, leaving their ranch in a debt due to a reverse mortgage,Toby thinks this is the best way to find the money to pay the debt.

Texas Rangers Marcus Hamilton (Jeff Bridges) and Alrberto Parker (Gil Birmingham) are assigned to the case. Hamilton is close to retire, he figure out the plan of the brothers Howard set in motion a plan to catch them with the help of Arlberto Parker. 

"Hell or Highwater" is considered by a neo-western film, because all the elements used to tale the story as well of the esthetics and look of the cowboy movies. After careful analysis you can tell the director David Mackenzie and writer Taylor Sheridan dig deeper into western movies to metaphorically represents two cowboys robbing banks looking for poetic justice, been chased by the sherif who is sure from the very beginning who is the mastermind in this crime. "Hell or Highwater" have several connotations of the struggle of the good vs evil, bringing the enigma of who is the real bad guy, like in Clint Eastwood "Unforgiven" as well social criticism to private institutions who sometimes are not the good guys, but the bad guys, just ripping people off, as a consequence there is a quest for full revenge.

The all star cast deliver a great performance and Nick Cave & Warren Ellis presents one of the finest original score on screen.
Easily one of the best films from the last 10 years.
How is this movie up for Best Picture?  It was okay, good at best, but not great.
Along with beautiful open landscapes, this neo-Western film shows the perspective of two opposite duos that were perfectly thought out during the writing process by Taylor Sheridan.
A few too many drawn out scenes of characters sitting on porches staring out onto empty horizons, but otherwise a very well made heist movie with some pretty hard-hitting moments and fun characters.

In a few years there will probably be a Rotten Tomato Scandal where we find out "certified fresh" is bought and sold by Hollywood insiders. This movie isn't so much bad as it's certified BULLSHIT!

A modern day western with masterful performances from Jeff Bridges as weathered Texas ranger and superb Ben Foster as the other half of a bank robbing duo. There is no clear-cut right and wrong and you just can't help but feel deep empathy for both sides. You can see this going wrong from the start but you just can't help cheering them on. The dialogue is snappy and the action explosive. This film also has the best ending of any film I've seen in a long time!
Very interesting and lots of action. well acted and great plot.

This is a very well-crafted mood piece that embodies a fresh take on the heist genre. Using the current US economic clash between the struggling working class and the banks as it's canvas, the director has cleverly created juxtaposing imagery, feelings and narrative drive that poignantly reflects themes at stake. The acting and music are just as affective too, which makes this thriller a must see.
Found the plot, acting, direction and soundtrack moving. Wish more films were this authentic.

A heist thriller packaged as a contemporary western with solid performances, dry humor and a social commentary on the effects of unguarded and insensitive capitalism. While it offers nothing new in terms of plot, narrative or screenplay - it more than makes up through confident direction, well defined character arcs and excellent performances throughout. 

Toby (Chris Pine) and Tanner (Ben Foster) are estranged brothers who led completely different lives - one (Toby) as a doting son, caring husband and father, while the other (Tanner) has been on the wrong side of the law from the beginning who has spent most of his time in various prisons for petty thefts and robberies. When the bank announces to foreclose their property due to unpaid debts just when Toby discovers oil in their farm, he is desperate to get possession of it before it is reclaimed by the bank forever. Toby comes up with a plan to rob the same bank (multiple of its branches) and seeks assistance from his brother Tanner who regularly agrees. What happens when the plan is set in motion and a retiring police chief Marcus from a small town starts investigating.

Chris Pine was a revelation in this role. While it is not intense or award worthy, he does complete justice by portraying a stubborn, meticulous and sometimes desperate man to get over with what they started. Jeff Bridges has some of the best lines though they range from being insensitive to downright racist - he surely offends Indian tribes, blacks, mexicans etc. along the way. But the dry humor he evokes along with his Indian partner are worth a second watch. The screenplay plays down many intense sequences to ensure they do not get sopped down or become melodramatic which would be inconsistent with the overall theme. 

The setup, the screenplay that reveals the plot without the characters saying it as a narrative shows the ability of the director about the confidence and the intensity shown in the 2013 'Starred Up' was a testimony to his talent. Jeff Bridges is one of the better contemporary Hollywood actors and his choice of roles has always been that extract maximum performance within the mainstream cinema. Ben Foster plays a very generic not so bright but trigger happy ex-con which has been played over many times but still done as good as it could be.

Sometimes innovation is not the only answer to standout. Perfection and old school intensity does work too.

There's no digital world like phones, computers et cetera, just an old fashioned storytelling. This is the story of two brothers and their series of bank robbery job. They are doing it for a reason, but on the other end, two cops make their effort to find who they are and nab them red handed. So when they meet, that's where the story gets to its end part.

It has a strong opening, then slows down. Actually, it was approached like a classic crime film, which mean no high-tech. The story was a one liner, but the events in that story were extended. A simple screenplay, yet very effective presented on the screen. Of course the story ends with this film, but feels like there's more. It is very unlikely, though I'm thinking of a sequel.

I watched it not knowing the meaning of the title, and then I googled it. It is nothing like a must see, but I believe that you might regret if you miss it or delay your watch. So I suggest you make a right choice.

Desperate times.  So this is about a pair of brothers in West Texas (Chris Pine, Ben Foster).  They're not professional criminals, but that doesn't change the fact that they are robbing small banks so as to raise the money needed to save their family ranch.  I love a good crime story.  The easiest way to make this type of story accessible is to make the criminals intelligent, but novices.  This way, you, as an audience member, can put yourself in the shoes of the protagonist, and you can picture yourself being able to pull off a heist if you ever became all out of options in your own life.  Hell or High Water does exactly that, and this is a riveting and compelling crime drama.  Now this is not a very complicated story.  It's men at the end of their rope, being forced into a crime that they otherwise wouldn't commit, all the while the law moves in closer and closer.  What makes this movie so good and the reason why this is being considered for Academy Awards is due to all of the attention to detail.  This is the most Texas movie since There Will Be Blood, and after all is said and done, you really feel like you've taken a personal trip to the state where everything's bigger, and not to its nicer, more progressive side.  I feel like I learned two things about Texas from this movie, the first item being that open carry is in full effect, and everybody in Texas is packing.  It helps add to tension in scenes being that you know that so many civilians could potentially pull out a gun and make the situation go from bad to worse.  The second item is that everyone's a little bit racist in this state.  Jeff Bridges gives a terrific performance as a Texan detective that is close to retirement.  He still has a little bit of that True Grit accent left over, and every other sentence out of his mouth is something racially offensive, which isn't aided by the fact that he has a Native American partner.  It's almost on that level of Gran Torino where you're unsure if this is a man who just thinks racial humor is funny, or if he could potentially be the biggest racist you've ever laid eyes on.  This movie would pair terrifically with No Country for Old Men.  It is well made and character driven, and you are always interested in how it will play out.  It's all about just how quickly a simple plan can go south, and you're rooting for these guys to succeed in addition to rooting for Jeff Bridges to catch them, so it makes for an intriguing dynamic.  There's some very appropriate music featured from Nick Cave, and every time there is a showdown, you hold your breath.  It's a good, simple movie, and I will always love a movie for getting the terrific Ben Foster more work.

Wow.  So...it was great - but it is not for someone seeking to be spoon fed typical Hollywood tripe, or if that is just your mood for the moment.   It unwinds slowly with just phenomenal character acting, and plays out like a poem.  The characters are deep but laconic, with every word as important as the surrounding silence it is embedded within.  In fact much is conveyed without words at all rather simply a look - you know, acting.  The setting and cinematography perfectly reveal the nature of windswept poverty, with the legacy of struggle so deep that is at once both invisible and pronounced in every character in the film - serving as backdrop and impetus for the characters of Chris Pine, Ben Hogan, and Jeff Bridges to intersect.  Beautifully directed - think Lasse Hallstrom combined with the Coen Brothers.  Highly recommend.

A wonderful film about two bank robbing brothers who are pursued by a determined Texas Ranger and his partner. The "Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid" of 2016. 

All four of the main actors deserve praise for their performances. Foster and Evans are convincing as brothers. Their banter is often times hilarious and feels like something real brothers would say to each other. Foster is particularly amazing at portraying Tanner as an "aw-shucks", charming yet lethal ex-con bank robber.  The audience can't help but like him, even though he can be a cold-blooded killer. Bridges and Birmingham give great performances as laid-back but serious Rangers on the trail of the two brothers. They are cool as beans even under gunfire. Badasses, without any posturing.

The plot is pretty straight-forward. The two brothers come up with a plan to rob from the very bank that is foreclosing on their family ranch. So they rob banks in order to come up with enough cash to pay off the bank. The story is simple but the great acting captures your attention and never lets go. Highly recommended.

Between the several bank-heist films I've seen, Hell or High Water is undoubtedly at the top. Sharing many similarities with Ben Affleck's The Town, it's about two brothers trying to secure enough money to pay off the mortgage of a very profitable piece of property. Chris Pine gives one of his best performances as one brother, and Ben Foster's performance is arguably his best. Echoing a very similar outlaw in the remake of 3:10 to Yuma, Foster does a great job of playing an unpredictable, unhinged sociopath. The performance is Oscar-nomination worthy at the very least. The first hour or so didn't impress me too much, but once the third act began, it quickly became a deeply engaging experience that I can confidently recommend to anyone that likes good acting and good storytelling.

I know the comparison will not be seen as favorable to some, but elements of this movie sure do remind me of No Country for Old Men.  And I mean stylistically speaking.  Thematically, they're both very different movies, because this one tells a more personal tale of two brothers trying to fuck over the banks who fucked over their mother by giving her a loan that she could not pay back.  They do this by stealing from several of the branches that fucked their mother over and using that money to pay the bank back, which is pretty clever if you actually think about it.  And it would be cool if someone could actually do that.  And maybe someone already has, but, of course, it's not something I would go around publicizing.  I think both movies do share some thematic elements as well, such as the old ranger close to retirement finding one more chance for a last hurrah after a series of bank robberies break out reminding me of Tommy Lee Jones' character in No Country.  And the cat and mouse game that ensues as both search for their respective suspects.  One of the, many, things I like about this movie is the fact that it all seems to be heading to one direction.  There's no real deviation from that main narrative path with subplots.  Nothing to distract you from the fact that the brothers and the rangers are on a collision course.  It's just a matter of time before they find each other and all hell breaks loose.  I know it's something very simple and something that, really, every movie should do.  Just focus on exactly what you want your story to be and how you want your characters to get there.  And I realize that a lot of movies do this, but it somehow doesn't feel as focused as it does in this movie.  There's a clear endgame in sight for the story and these characters and it's just a matter of seeing how they get there.  The film is definitely very confident in the pace that it wants to tell its story.  They do not rush through any scenes and everything in the film serves a purpose, there's no wasted moments here.  All of it works to add up to the climax, which you know will be bloody and you know people will die.  So, yea, I really liked that.  Do I feel that the movie was great?  I don't know, I honestly don't feel like it was.  I think it was missing something.  While I do like the fact that the brothers pay the banks back with their own (stolen) money, I feel that the movie pretty much hit every plot point I could have reasonably expected from them.  I don't wanna say it's completely predictable, but you can see where certain things are headed before they happen.  I did like the fact that the reason Chris Pine's character did what he did was to avenge what the banks had done to his mother, but also to give his sons a future where they wouldn't have to worry about money because of the oil that was found on his land.  I liked all of that for sure.  I also thought the writing was strong and the acting was excellent.  Chris Pine and Jeff Bridges really are phenomenal here, but, to me, Ben Foster steals the show.  Ben is as underrated as they come and this is just another feather in his cap.  I can't complain about the acting in the slightest and anyone who does is clearly looking for something, anything, to hate about this movie.  But, as I said, there was just something missing that would have pushed it past the great level and maybe made it a modern classic in a couple of years' time.  I can see how people might already see it as a great movie, but I just don't.  That's not to say it isn't a damn good movie that you should see, because it is and I would definitely give it a recommendation.  But just go in with tempered expectations.  Great acting and strong writing, so, yea, you can't really go wrong here.

WHAT  I LIKED: This is real back to basics cinema brought into the modern age; a study of two well-developed character groups in plots wonderfully at odds with each other. Instead of mindless action and black and white good or bad, intense focus is drawn to the writing, cinematography and amazing performances, and as a result this is one of the most satisfying experiences of the year. Don't go thinkin' it aint got style though, because the tight humour and solid score deliver a home run in that department too.
WHAT I DIDN'T LIKE: Once it's got going, the plot is rather basic 'highway to the end' stuff, which makes it feel a little dragged out.
VERDICT: A well constructed movie from Mackenzie that's brilliant elements aren't quite given the time to shine by the plot direction. It is full of brilliant stuff, though

'Hell or High Water' is a Western Crime Drama that substitutes the large scale chaotic shootouts for great character depth and exploration of character relationships. Starring Chris Pine, Jeff Bridges, and Ben Foster this film follows two brothers Toby (Pine) and Tanner (Foster) robbing banks to set up a better future for themselves, but they soon find themselves being tracked down by rangers Marcus (Bridges) and Alberto (Gil Birmingham) who are going for one last hunt before retirement. Performance-wise this film shines above most others to have released this year, as you completely bought into the characters at the forefront of the film and you believed the authenticity and history of their relationships without seeing any of it. Pine and Bridges especially are the standouts on either sides of the law. From a story perspective it was great to see a contemporary Western film take advantage of the characters they have and really delve deep into who they are and let those relationships and actions drive the course of the film. Because without engaging, and entertaining characters there is no reason for investment in any shootouts that may or may not occur.

The character centric nature of the film is what makes it so compelling for so long. On one hand, following the lives of these two brothers and seeing how they connect and clash with their different personalities and values offered a very complex look at these characters. Are they good people? Are they doing it for good reasons? Are they hurting people for the fun of it? Exploring all of these questions throughout the film put you on a journey with these two who you may grow to love or hate with time. And then you also have the film focusing on Marcus and Alberto and their journey just casually investigating some bank robberies and tracking down the brothers. This was a relationship that was also just as interesting as that between the brothers but for very different reasons. The way these partners go back and forth, throwing friendly insults and butting heads but ultimately tolerating each others company was a nice comparison and contrast to the relationship being shown with our bank robbers. 

The slow, gradually intensifying pacing did a good job at keeping you interested for the majority of the film but could have done with a little bit of a kick somewhere in the middle of the film. It noticeably slows down for a 20 minute interval around half way through, and some of that period of time did have some interesting character dialogue happening but it was starting to lose me a little. It does then pick back up and finish very strong which was really good to see it not continue to slow down and fizzle out in the end which was a fear for around 10 minutes.

As i mentioned the performances in this film are definitely some of the strongest of the year, and although it may be a little early to tell, i wouldn't be too surprised if one of them gets a nod at the Academy Awards. Chris Pine for me was the strongest of the bunch, seeing him play a very subdued role and a different role to what he is typically cast in was very refreshing. He didn't once break character and when the movie started i thought i was going to be distracted seeing him in this Texan role but he worked his magic and i completely bought into him as this character. Ben Foster also should be recognised because he plays well together with Pine and the back and forth conversations they have are interesting on their own. Jeff Bridges is playing a character that he has more or less played in many other Western/Crime films but he is just so good in the role that you wouldn't want anyone else. 

So 'Hell or High Water' is a really solid film that is very well crafted and features great all round performances and a very compelling character centric story. You get on board with these characters and are on a journey with both sides of the law so you feel a connection with both sets of characters making pivotal moments in the film that much more intense. 

8/10

This film is a perfect neo-western with outstanding performances by Ben Foster, Jeff Bridges, and Chris Pine as well as a whole host of background characters. At first this film seems to only appeal to the western fanbase-- to those who crave good men doing bad things or bad men doing what's right-- but the soul of this film is something everyone who ever loved their family can get attached to. It's tension filled. emotional, thoughtful, and a great, chugging-along drama. It offers an escape from the CGI smashfests and welcomes you to a world of a decaying America, full of history and spirit. A must watch for 2016 and a criminally under-exposed picture.

Best film of the year (so far). A modern-day Western set against the bleak landscape of the fossil fuel industry's boom-and-bust cycle nadir, where only the banks make out unless the tables are turned.

Excellent performances all around support an intricate and always riveting plot where the line between right and wrong becomes blurred, and lives are essentially swapped in what plays out as a zero-sum game - except life isn't a game. 

While this can be seen strictly as a bank-robbery-shoot-em-up film, the undercurrent of dire poverty in rural America where the promises of good jobs and comfortable lives give way to the very real struggles for survival make this a memorable and great film. Definitely, modern-day shades of Grapes of Wrath meets Bonnie & Clyde meets Unforgiven.

Hell or High Water is a Western directed by David Mackenzie and stars Chris Pine as Toby, a divorced father of two in need of money to pay his recently deceased mother's debts in order to establish a stable life for his sons. With the help of his other brother, Tanner (Ben Foster: OSCAR WATCH), Toby takes to robbing small-town banks. A law enforcement officer (Jeff Bridges) and his partner (Gil Birmingham) try to catch the criminals.

I read about this movie in a magazine this past Summer before its limited release and was intrigued by the idea of Chris Pine starring in a small-scale independent film. The magazine praised his performance almost as much as they praised Ben Foster's, and other reviews for the limited release echoed these sentiments. Finally, the movie was released digitally, so I had an opportunity to see what the hype was about. Hot damn, was this movie fun!

This is a drama first and foremost. As much as we all love shoot-em-ups, it's good to see a crime film with such richly developed characters. Ben Foster has never been better - watch out for him come awards season for Supporting Actor. His troubled past and care for his younger brother really define him. Chris Pine came to play, too. We know him for his blockbuster hits like Star Trek, but he showed that he can tone it down and deliver an emotional performance as well. Jeff Bridges is exactly what you'd want Jeff Bridges to be when portraying a southern cop; his relationship with his partner reminded me of Hank and his partner from Breaking Bad, and both of their characters had depth beyond chasing the crooks as well. David Mackenzie is not a name I'm familiar with, but he really crafted something big here. The beautiful scenic shots of rural Texas, in addition to the perfect film score, really gives this setting an authentic feeling.

Overall, this movie has everything I want from an independent drama: solid writing, outstanding acting, and emotions. Hopefully this marks a turning point in the two young stars' careers.

Final grade: A

-Ben

Hell or High Water is an amazing and gripping western heist film. It stars Chris Pine, Ben Foster, Jeff Bridges, and Gil Birmingham. Chris Pine and Ben Foster play brothers who start robbing banks for a personal reason. Chris Pine and Ben Foster both deliver career defining performances and have great on screen chemistry. Chris Pine delivers a subtle and emotionally reserved performance, that really cements him as a great dramatic actor. Ben Foster turns in what I think is the best performance of the movie and his career. He plays an unpredictable, charismatic, and borderline-crazy ex-con. His character commits horrid actions towards the end of the movie, and other things he's done are hinted at, but he's so likable thanks to Foster's performance and the script, that it's extremely difficult to dislike or root against him. Jeff Bridges play's an aging soon to retire texas ranger, who takes on one more case before leaving the force for good. He delivers a performances akin to True Grit (2010) and Crazy Heart (2009). He turns in a great performance, one that deserves a spot on his decade spanning filmography. He has great chemistry with his partner, played by Gil Birmingham, and it was fun to watch them interact and try and track down the bank robbers (Pine and Foster). This film has great direction, and thats thanks to David Mackenzie. He previously directed Starred Up, one of my personal favorite films of 2013. He's great at directing characters, scenery, and action. The script was written by Taylor Sheridan who has a great track record, this being his second script after Sicario, which was one of my favorites of 2015. Here he crafts great dialogue, interesting and believable characters, and is able to mix in elements of comedy, with creating an inconsistent tone. The score by Nick Cave and Warren Ellis is great, and really helps set the scene, set the tone, and build tension. Finally the cinematography by Giles Nuttgens is great, and there are some really good shots in this film. I'd say this a must see, and I'd recommend watching it as soon as you can.

Hell or High Water has a simple story with details that are revealed slowly as we get to now the characters and their plans, troubles etc. Texas is also a huge character in this film. It shows us the people who live in the loose regulatory environment of the flat, relatively empty parts of the American South, the people we know voted for Trump and,for me at least, humanized them. 
Hell or High Water also has a very important political message that is a catalyst for the plot and only needs a short speech to make it clear what this movie is saying about what money has done to the barren, poor South. 
The performances are also excellent across the board. It is great to see Ben Foster getting more work and hopefully he'll get some recognition come awards season because he owns this film.

Interesting lines:
"You never understood that fighting back makes the beating last longer." -  Toby (Chris Pine)
"You know what Comanche means.  It means enemies forever." - Bear (Gregory Cruz)
"You know what that makes me?  A Comanche." - Tanner
"You tell me not to be like you and then you offer me a beer.  Which is it?" - Justin Howard (John-Paul Howard)

 

Funny lines:

"This is our uniform." - Alberto Parker (Gil Birmingham)
"You want to hear about these robberies or just sit there and let Alzheimer's run its course?" - Alberto
"Could you tell their race?  Black?  White?" - Marcus

Relying on the action and the odd half sentence sustained this viewer with an intriguing narrative albeit set against the depressing backdrop of a post '08 financial crash. The desolately flat dusty Texas landscape felt all the more foreboding with the spectre of an imminent threat of a Trump administration and a nation seemingly stuck in a gun-toting time-warp. While the exact motive of this hapless pair on the rampage remained obscure, the sub-text of a remote America impoverished by the clash of old values and lifestyle with the realities of social and financial hardship painted a melancholic picture.

'Hell or High Water' is a modern twist on the classic western genre, replacing shoot-em-up action sequences with heartfelt character studies that hold interest, even with its intentionally slow pace.

Wonderfully atmospheric. Superb cinematography. A slow burner that focuses on the brothers' relationship and the relationship between the two cops who are investigating the crimes. The cast are excellent; the sound track fits the mood perfectly; the humour is intelligent and genuinely funny; and there are some tense moments that punctuate the plot. This movie focuses more on character than action - but is totally engaging.  Don't miss it.

It's about five minutes into this gritty crime drama-which kicks off with a long unbroken tracking shot-that you know you're in for something special. And the remainder of the film, all the way up until the bittersweet closing shot, doesn't disappoint. The story is set in a post-GFC West Texas and follows two bank-robbing brothers who have underlying motives to their unlawful actions (to tell would spoil the narrative's wonderful drip-feed style), whilst also tracking the soon-to-be-retired Ranger who's seeking to finish his career on a high. Taylor Sheridan's screenplay is remarkably simple yet effective, wisely resisting the temptation to resort to thriller-ish tropes despite ostensibly playing like one. He allows the multi-layered characters to do all the heavy lifting and is rewarded with a cast that absolutely nails it. As polar opposite siblings who share an unbreakable bond, Chris Pine and Ben Foster are magnetic; the former a level-headed brooder with the weight of the world on his shoulders, the latter an unpredictable live wire who would gladly kill for his younger brother. On the other side of the fence, Jeff Bridges brings his A-game as a sardonic law-enforcement veteran who is equal parts intelligent and stubborn, terrifically supported by an understated Gil Birmingham as his oft-tormented partner. Most impressively the film doesn't seem to pass judgment on any of the characters (or at least not until late in the piece), allowing them to exist without labelling them good or bad; they all have parts of themselves that fit into both categories. Director David Mackenzie also deserves a lot of praise, as he sublimely balances the need for a tight and tense plot whilst simultaneously allowing his characters ample room to breathe and grow. Mackenzie also gets the very best out of his cinematographer Giles Nuttgens who delivers bold, sharp and stylish camera movements in addition to a level of photography (i.e., lighting and framing) that is as good as you'll see this year. Narratively powerful, visually mesmerising and backed to Nick Cave's transcendent soundtrack, Hell or High Water is one of the finest motion pictures of 2016.

Call me simplistic but when I go to a movie I like to either be rooting for a character or not rooting for them. In this movie, it was hard to pick which way to go. After I left, it is possible that some strong women characters suddenly materialised but it would have been too little, too late. If the director of this movie has a high opinion of women he is doing his best to hide that fact.

This is a modern western about two very different brothers who rob banks in an economically depressed West Texas to raise the money they need to save their family farm.   It's also an ethical thriller, which left me wondering who was bad - the robbers, or what they robbed.  Great action sequences and cinematography made it visually exciting, but the stand out was the performance of Jeff Bridges as the Texas Ranger in pursuit of the robbers.  Highly recommended and a movie that I suspect will be appearing in a number of award nominations over coming weeks.

Hell or High Water is probably the intelligent drama you have been searching for that also includes a good slice of action, suspense and comedy. In fact it's one of the best cinema experiences this year. Even though the story is nothing new it's supremely well done. Armed with a great script and flawless performances this film moves with good pace and great heart. Two brothers revert to robbing banks to save their late mother's ranch. They are complicated characters whose path is known but there are surprises along the way. All the actors are great but Jeff Bridges steals the show as the crusty Texas ranger hunting them down. To add another layer there is plenty of succinct commentary on the state of America, especially the woes of rural Texas. Oh, one more thing, the score by Nice Cave and Warren Ellis just adds to the pleasure.

David Mackenzie's electrifying, captivating desperado action-drama. About two brothers, one a divorced father, Tanner, played superbly by Ben Foster and the other Toby, played impressively by Chris Pine in a scene-stealing performance, who is a hot-headed ex-convict with a lose trigger finger. Both Foster and Pine share great chemistry as brothers who plan a series of brazen robberies against the bank that is about to foreclose on their family ranch, to make a better life for Tanner's young son and themselves. But standing in their way is Marcus, played brilliantly by old pro Jeff Bridges, a crafty, hardened veteran Texas Ranger about to retire in a few weeks. As the brothers prepare for their final heist, they must also get ready for a showdown with this relentless lawman. Astute direction by Mackenzie, who gives his wonderful film suspense, humor and some heartfelt tragic moments. Gorgeous cinematography by Glles Nuttgens, and a perfect original score by Nick Cave & Warren Ellis. An engaging modern western. Highly recommenced.

Chris Pine gives the best performance of his career I've ever seen, and while Jeff Bridges is basically being Jeff Bridges, he's just so damn good at it.

This movie definitely caught my attention from the beginning. The start had no speaking just music (great musical score), of driving down a rural West Texas highway and the problems that plague the local population of farm owners by showing billboards of bank acquired land for sale accompanied by area economic collapse. Then it pans to two middle aged men who quickly mask themselves and walk into a small town bank. The two men, Chris Pine (Star Trek) and Ben Foster (3:10 To Yuma) play "The Howard" brothers who live very different lives (one a jailbird and the other a family man rancher), but have an unbreakable bond towards family and will do anything to preserve their home, culture and life by robbing small town banks to pay off their recently deceased Mothers mortgage on their land. The viewers soon learn that this is a last option for the brothers, knowing that they need to pay back the banks within a week. They soon rob many banks quickly in the area and get the attention of the local Texas Rangers office and their old/ready to retire head ranger Jeff Bridges (Crazy Heart) who signs up using his experience as a detective to catch the local bandits. This movie becomes a cat and mouse game of bank robbers who have a running clock towards losing their home and an old Texas Ranger who wants one last hoorah before retiring. One side is going to win. Small characters like Katy Mixon, Marin Ireland, and Gil Birmingham (mostly television work) also portray their characters to perfection.

Chris Pine, Ben Foster and Jeff Bridges all should win an Academy Award for their performances and this movie should at least be nominated for the best of the 2016-2017 season. Please go see it! Thank me later.

Few films can deliver everything to moviegoers seeking the most bang for their box office buck.  Drama and comedy, perhaps.  Maybe even some sentimental chick flick mixed in with a thrilling suspense story.  Now toss in a modern Western cowboy feature with risky bank robberies in the Lone Star State.  For a motion picture to invoke each of these film genres in the same movie, airtight scripts must come alive through magnificent screen performances.  "Hell or High Water" powerfully achieves both and is by far the best film I've seen this year!

The shear strength of "Hell or High Water" resides in one of the strongest ensemble casts of 2016 and an authentic, captivating story to tell.  Academy Award winner Jeff Bridges stars as a long in the tooth Texas Ranger named Marcus Hamilton, who desires to bring swift justice to the pair of bank bandits before his pending retirement. 

Bridges may be the film's most accomplished and notable Hollywood face, but his performance is matched along every stretch of west Texas highway by a very formidable Ben Foster ("Lone Survivor"). Riding shotgun to Foster's volatile Tanner Howard character is none other than "Star Trek Beyond" captain Chris Pine, portraying Tanner's younger brother Toby.  Together this trio play a game of cat and mouse, with viewers hoping no losers emerge in the end.  Credit the veteran Bridges for bringing out the career film bests for both Foster and Pine.

This film may be promoted as two brothers robbing banks, however, it's more about two give-and-take relationships.  These dueling bonds consist of one representing the law with Bridges' and his Texas Ranger sidekick, the other a brotherhood of outlaws raised in an abusive household.  One rapport the culmination of years serving together and the other a result of years spent apart.

Wielding a razor-sharp script from Taylor Sheridan (who wrote last year's phenomenal "Sicario" screenplay), "Hell or High Water" backs up to their getaway car with deeply satisfied theater audiences in close chase.  And combined with remarkable cinematography brandishing vast lands and small town life, "Hell or High Water" has confidently ordered all other 2016 films to get down on the floor and not move. At least for now.  

In 2012, "Hell or High Water" earned The Black List award for the most liked motion picture "screenplay not yet produced" from voters consisting of studio and production company executives. Historically, over 25% of the screenplays making The Black List have later earned an Oscar nomination, including; "Argo", "American Hustle", "The King's Speech", "Slumdog Millionaire", "Spotlight" and "The Revenant".  Not bad company.  

Is "Hell or High Water" a shoo-in for an Academy Award nomination come January?  You can bank on it.

Hell or High Water is a no-holds barred, modern-day western, that masterfully weaves a layered and powerful crime story that is quite honestly; the best Coen Brothers film I've ever seen that they had no part in. The style, writing, cinematography, and script definitely owe a lot to films like Blood Simple and No Country For Old Men, but it certainly stands on its own! The film centers on two brothers, played brilliantly by Chris Pine and Ben Foster, who begin robbing the banks that have screwed their family over in an attempt at a Robin Hood-style revenge while a grizzled, Texas Ranger played by Jeff Bridges, pursues. Chris Pine and Ben Foster have immaculate chemistry together and though it's great to see a rougher side to Pine, Ben Foster steals this entire movie as the unstable side of the equation who's already done time in prison and will not go back. Jeff Bridges is also the best he's been in years here, using a Southern drawl not dissimilar to his delivery in True Grit, and his best moments are the playful banter he has with his partner, played by Gil Birmingham who is definitely the break-out actor here! The film is directed by David Mackenzie, who's made a couple films prior, but this will clearly be his break-out film and he deserves much praise for crafting an air-tight film that never stopped surprising me. The script is written by Taylor Sheridan, who also wrote Sicario, and features much of the same grit and realism while crafting some truly bad-ass scenarios for the characters to take part in. This is not a super fast-paced film, it spends time developing its very strong characters, but when the bullets do fly, the tone completely shifts and you will be holding your breath during the shoot-outs, car chases, and pretty much the entire climax. I absolutely loved this film and it really proves that the script is key, and you don't have to to attempt over-blown action and A-list movie stars to get the job done. Hell or High Water is a flawless film that will stand out for years to come, and I cannot wait to watch it again!

Heavy handed depression-era story set thoughtlessly in modern day Texas with no concern for the current state of affairs.   Firstly the portrayal of west Texas as a region suffering from decay and predatory banking is astonishingly irrelevant to modern day - a period of intense growth and low unemployment in the state.  Worst of all, the film's "solution" for the protagonist's poverty revolves around the discovery of oil on his property.  This is 2016!  Oil prices are so low that existing oil wells are shutting down...not opening up to make new millionaires.  Also the big oil industry is in North Dakota now.   Why on earth is this film set in Texas 2016???  If you want to write a sob story about Texas, then make it about bad traffic or set it back in time 100 years!
Tweakers don't sleep, they just tweak.

The lead characters drive the film.  Chris Pine is the thinking alpha male with a plan.  Ben Foster is the bank robbing adrenaline seeking brother. All the characters and story development  creates  a social message about poverty, and taking care of one's own problems  which collides with a violent climax. The new movie from David Mackzenie (director of the critically adored Starred Up) and Taylor Sheridan (screenwriter of the extraordinary drug cartel thriller Sicario) is the much heralded contemporary western crime saga, Hell Or High Water.

Set against a backdrop of corporate corruption and recession hit America, Hell Or High Water is a chase movie with a conscience. Jeff Bridges plays Marcus Hamilton, a wily Texas Ranger who is about to retire, hunting two bank robbing brothers, Toby and Tanner Howard (Chris Payne and Ben Foster) who are hoping to raise enough money to save their family farm which is under threat of foreclosure from the bank they're robbing.

Pine and Foster are a superb double act as chalk and cheese brothers but the pair are eclipsed by Bridges who puts in a career best performance for which he's likely to get nominations come award season. In addition to some memorable supporting roles, edgy script and dark humour; the striking visuals of long flat landscapes, empty skies and hardscrabble communities together with an expansive, melancholic soundtrack, beautifully depicts a blighted Texas and of an age gone by.

Whist the plot is pretty conventional, grizzly cops and outlaw siblings with violent tempers are hardly a novelty, Hell Or High Water is a riveting heist movie with action and drama that maintains the suspense with the audience never knowing where they stand. One of the best films of the year, a new Western classic and an award contender.

The modern American western film has got a makeover over the past decade, with works of art like 'No Country for Old Men' earning praise from critics and attendance at the box office. In CBS Film's 'Hell or High Water,' the best and worst aspects of West Texas are highlighted as two brothers rob banks and make bank.

Chris Pine and Ben Foster tag-team as amateur bandits in the film, cruising through dusty plains in search of easy target branches of the Texas Midlands Bank. The reason? To grab enough cash to ensure their deceased mother's ranch does not fall into foreclosure and be claimed by the bank. The plot is a great example of the dog-eat-dog cycle that can result in this kind of a "wild wild west," "anything goes" environment, and the accompanying screenplay clearly conveys this. The aforementioned actors bring their A-game, with Foster giving a particularly convincing performance thanks to his 'bad boy' persona. But it is the legendary Jeff Bridges who steals the show as his role as nearly-retired Lubbock sheriff Marcus Hamilton.

In addition to the solid story and potentially award nomination-worthy acting, 'High Water' is a classically told drama that benefits from its simpleness. At the heart of the film is the concept of family, and the lengths to which some will go to ensure the lives of their children are better than their own are. Pine's character helps this come across, as he is seen as a sympathetic figure despite his criminality. Also, the duality between him and his brother is stark, which is perhaps the reason they make a successful team. But it is the dialogue that really brings everything together, with Bridges' quips and rifle barrel banter adding enough flare.

While 'Hell or High Water' likely won't win many awards thanks to a likely crowded field during the fall and winter, it's a strong, small-budget effort that should be highly regarded.

I was a little worried as the movie started and it seemed like the focus was off, yet I could still read the names printed on the screen so I chalked it up as wannabe low budget cinematics.  I realize now that it was intentional. You get a feel for the pace and tone as the movie goes along.
I will say the pace is....Texan.  Not slow, but a bit drawn out, and since it's set in Texas, this too must be intentional.  Beautifully calculated mixed with the most unusual yet stunning music, scenery, and humor.  I was laughing at some very inappropriate jokes, but I couldn't help it! Did I mention the scenery?  The sky. I've always said the best thing about Texas is how huge the sky is.  You can see this in the film, several times.  That with the sweat, flies, music, and bank robbing, make it a real "western".
Oh, the acting-I almost forgot to talk about it because it was so good, I didn't feel like any of them were acting, I just felt like I was there. Taken from my real day to day crap and plopped in the middle of Texas on a hellish day 'bout ta have me sum fun.  And that's all and everything I want in a movie.

What defines a "western"? Is it cowboys? Guns? Horses? Boots? Or is it its morals of American masculinity itself; a study of what does, and what should, make a man? No matter what the criteria, Hell or High Water fits. Sure, it's not the typical period piece fare we normally get from the genre, but it's a wonderfully old-fashioned yarn that would've been a hit in most bygone eras. Only an "indie" by the most basic description, its qualitative and crowd-pleasing reach much exceeds its financial grasp. Boasting funny, enthralling, and character-filled fun from start to finish, this unconventional cowboy chronicle is the movie we've wanted all year.
It's the story of the bank-robbing Howard brothers (Pine, Foster) and the nearly-retired lawman (Bridges) who's hot on their tales. The script is perfect, from the dialogue to the plotting to the characters to the themes. The simplicity of its cat-and-mouse setup allows the thematic and ethical complexities to unravel as the story does, instead of forcing it through hackneyed exposition. Touching on topics like the dangers of nostalgia, flawed justice, colonialism, and western heroism, its thematic richness is only matched by its penetrating visuals.
With anti-hero films filling the cinematic landscape nowadays, this is more a "pro-human" film. We find ourselves "rooting" for everyone, not because they're necessarily "justified", but because we know them. Director MacKenzie is a proven actors-director, and the performances here are utterly naturalistic and masterful. Along with a wonderful soundtrack and grimily stellar sets and costumes, it's an enveloping viewing experience you feel like you're living. As entertainingly cool as it is penetratingly artful, HoHW is far-and-away my favorite film of 2016.

Going into this one, I was very excited.  The trailer and the fact that it was written by Taylor Sheridan, the writer responsible for the terrific Sicario, had me all in on this one.

It had a basic, but entertaining story line revolving around bank robbers and the marshals tracking them down.  It had a Western, Neo Noir feel.  Great acting throughout led by Chris Pine, Ben Foster, Gil Birmingham and the great Jeff Bridges.  They bring their characters to life and help make the story more believable and real.   

There were some great comedic spots, mainly between the marshals, mixed with some thrilling action sequences.  It had a gritty, real-life feel thanks to the setting of a dusty, small town in West Texas.  The cinematography was great, with more than a few wonderful shot selections.

The only thing I disliked about this film is that it felt like something was missing.  I can't put my finger on it, but to me the film isn't perfection.  I had the same issue with Sicario also; maybe I should check out some more films written by Taylor Sheridan and see if I have the same feeling.

With all of this said, I would most definitely recommend Hell or High Water.

This is the second movie I have seen by writer Taylor Sheridan who also wrote the best film I saw last year, Sicario. The film is as dusty and desolate as the west Texas towns it features. It stars Jeff Bridges as a ruggedly ragged, past his prime Texas Ranger who needs the thrill of one last manhunt before he is put out to pasture. His performance is subtle and powerful, proving again that he is one of the best actors working today. Chris Pine (Star Trek's Captain Kirk) plays Toby, the older and more rational brother of thrill seeking Ben Foster's Tanner, two men forced by the many failures in their lives into robbing banks.

The brothers are on a desperate quest to steal and launder enough money from several small town bank branches to pay off the reverse mortgage their dying mother took out before the bank repossesses their family ranch and the rich oil deposits that lie beneath it. The brother's know their mother was taken advantage of by the same banks that they now steal from. Toby's meticulous plan to rob the banks is slowly unraveled as his uncontrollable brother ratchets up the violence and risk after each successive robbery.

The cinematography is unflinching in showing us a dying American culture.  Small towns are filled with payday loan stores, shuttered businesses and the hopelessness of people with no future. The only ones profiting from this desperation are the financial institutions that use poverty to their advantage to squeeze the last remaining value out of people with no other options.

This film is a metaphor for the struggle between the ever declining American middle and lower class folks who slip deeper and deeper in debt and the financial institutions who legally shake them down for every last nickel and then leave them destitute. One steals with impunity and is protected by the laws it pays politicians to write, the other steals for survival and faces certain death or imprisonment if captured.

It is ultimately a story of brotherhood, both blood and badge, of failure and redemption, and of repayment of debts owed. It is a modern day Robin Hood tale without a happy ending. In a season of sequels and blockbusters, this small, quiet film portrays the despondency of small town America and it's need to grasp onto something, anything, that gives it hope. Even if that hope is in the form of yet another smooth talking rich guy who will smile and shake their hands while he steals their future and pads his own pockets (Yeah, I figured out a way to criticize Trump with my review).

Jeff Bridges is also good, although his performance appears strongly influenced by Tommy Lee Jones in No Country for Old Men.

A few years ago, David Mackenzie gave us Starred Up, an entertaining, well crafted and socially relevant project that boasted some of most impressive acting of the year. In 2016 he does the same with Hell or High Water, a low-concept, straight-to-the-point, quietly explosive Texan extravaganza. Mackenzie grounds viewers in a lawless world, one plagued by poverty, debt and the imminence of death, and rewards them with rich character drama and excellent performances.

In Hell Or High Water, two brothers Tanner (Ben Foster) and Toby (Chris Pine) come together to rob a string of banks owned by the same organization that is threatening to foreclose on their family land. Things quickly turn serious as they are hunted by the area sheriff Marcus (Jeff Bridges) and his partner Alberto Parker (Gil Birmingham). While I wasn't quite as in love with it as the critics' consensus, the film holds it own with solid quality.

Watching Hell Or High Water wouldn't have been nearly as enjoyable without the solid cast. Jeff Bridges and Ben Foster were amazing bringing in some of the strongest performances I've seen this year. Bridges' character Marcus is on his way out the door as sheriff, but you get the feeling he's been doing nothing but speaking his mind (in a non-pc way) long before he knew he was retiring. He's extremely stubborn, not knowing how to let things go. Five minutes with Marcus on-screen and you can probably name someone in your life just like him. He's relatable while Foster's character Tanner is completely off his rocker. He's the guy you see coming and you cross the street, that person you know that asks you to hang out but you avoid them at all costs because you know how the night's going to end up. While Tanner is the type of person that has never run across any trouble that he didn't like, he's also endearing to a certain extent as his sole purpose is to help out his brother.

My one gripe with the movie is that the action fizzles in certain spots. Mind you, it's not supposed to be an action movie so I wasn't grossly disappointed, but I expected slightly more from a movie that has a lot to do with bank robberies. Again, not the end of the world, I just want to make sure I tame expectations ahead of time.

At the end of the day, the movie is not about the action but about the relationships between brothers and cops which you come to learn isn't really all that different. Brothers, just like cops, always tend to have each others' backs even when one hates what the other does. In one scene, Tanner finds himself in trouble with two guys at a gas station. Toby scolds Tanner for putting himself in such a position, but not before he beats the crap out of one of the guys and causes the other guy to run away. Meanwhile, Marcus' constant ribbing of his partner Alberto is a typical sign of love and respect. At first you think Marcus is a flat-out racist, but you quickly come to understand that he's trying to pass the sheriff torch in his own way. The insults he throws at Alberto are not just funny, but, in a weird way, a little touching.

Hell Or High Water is highly entertaining even without big-budget action sequences. I give it an 85.

Hell or High Water has to be the best movie of the year.  If you have had it with the usual dull crop of mindless blockbusters this refreshing soulful spellbinder is for you.  The death of the American dream  is etched in the vast, dusty landscape of the West Texas plains, the setting of this modern day Western.  Yet the brilliant direction and the stellar performances by all the actors offer  comical interludes that prevent this movie from becoming heavy or ponderous.  The unexpected conclusion is uplifting and will stay with you long after the movie is over.

This is the kind of film I wish could become the big blockbuster success at the box office in August/September. The thing that Hell or High Water had in spades, that every other film I saw in a theater this summer lacked, is well-developed interesting characters. They managed to make me care about every single main character, and sympathize with them all. There are few stories that I can remember where one character is pursuing another and I both want the pursuit to be successful, but also don't want the targeted character to get caught. That kind of internal conflict is such a complex and fascinating combination of emotions, that it takes a truly special film to give me that experience. The plot itself is revealed slowly, which keeps you dialed in and watching intently for what will happen next. I love that the movie found it more important to spend the early scenes establishing why we should like Chris Pine and Ben Foster rather than why they are doing what they are doing. It's a clever plan when they finally reveal everything, and it helped me to connect with them even more. Jeff Bridges and Gil Birmingham were spectacular, and their teasing banter back and forth was delightful. In many ways they act like a set of brothers, in order to perfectly mirror the brothers they are pursuing. The relationships between all of the characters comes across as very authentic, because this is how real people act with their coworkers, family, and so forth. When I left the theater I thought "Man, that was a good movie." But as I've had more time to sit with it I keep recalling scenes that I loved, moments that impacted me, lines that made me laugh, and so much more. Hell or High Water exceeded all of my expectations and is easily one of my favorite films of 2016.

A damn near perfect film from talented director Mackenzie and writer of the similarly confident, slow-burn thriller Sicario. It's the voice of of the characters that really sets the film apart. So few film writers have the same level of voice as do playwrights. It is due to that voice that this film about two bank robbing brothers stands out and above any bank heist or Western genre films from recent memory. Set in the recession-plagued dust of West Texas two brothers set to robbing branches of the bank that is set to foreclose on the land they grew up on. 

Foster has the showier role as the loose-cannon brother with a criminal history. He is afforded shades of character in both his love for his brother and the unexpected backstory that conflicts with his love of crime. Foster has a tendency to overact and that is still true here, but Mackenzie keeps him reigned in enough so that he doesn't topple the deliberate pace of the film. Pine plays the other brother who is motivated by love of family. It'll get less attention, but Pine turns off the smarm and seems lived-in with his soft-spoken Toby determined and cautious as the jobs grow more dangerous.

The authorities are hot on their heels, as the brothers only rob drawers in denominations of 20 and under. The cat and mouse factor is keyed in by about to retire Jeff Bridges. One last case and all that jazz. The trickiest part of the film is balancing the humor (because it does have a few good laughs) from Bridges' politically incorrect Ranger without it becoming a distraction. His partner is Mexian and Native American, and nigh a scene goes by without Bridges' character making a crack about it. It seems that it's there to make a point about these old ideas and old places dying away. His partner Alberto, is shown being hurt by the comments, and in turn Bridges seems hurt that his "humor" isn't found funny. It does enough to humanize Alberto (and the added bonus of a strong performance from Birmingham) that it plays as a critique of Old West dying in the face of New West.

As Toby and Tanner close in on their final goal (which isn't fully revealed until well into the film) everything culminates into one very well-staged shootout. Real stakes are present, and the filmmaking never falters. Mackenzie's opening long-shot is a panoramic beauty, and really sets the stage for the intentional pace and explosions of unexpected and visceral violence. And for a Scot he does a great job of making Texas a character in the film. From the vistas and dust to the running gag of everyone having a gun. Throw in a score from Western specialist Nic Cave & Warren Ellis and you have familiar elements rearranged just enough, and with enough expertise it feels new and exciting.

Outside of some obvious ADR and the wince-inducing racist jokes, there is only a few other passages of dialogue that hit a bit on the nose (white people taking Indian land, banks taking it back). It also sticks the landing in the fatalistic ways you expect, and in a way you may not. It's a gem of a film that deserves to be more than an indie favorite. A victory for mid-budget adult-film making.

From the bank robbers to the eye witnesses to the law enforcement to the native peoples, everybody senses that they were left out. And everybody has a quip that captures it. The morality - and chaos - that is left behind may not be new, but it is well crafted. Bridges and Pine are electric, and every minute is riveting.

Awards season has truly begun now, Hell or High Water is about two brothers robbing small bank branches whist being pursued by two rangers across Texas. This film was not in my anticipated list at all, I was not even remotely excited to watch this when the first trailer came out...then the reviews came in. With such high ratings, I had to see what all the fuss was about and I can honestly say the high ratings are justified. Hell or High Water is so close to perfection, so close! What brings this film to those heights you ask? The acting. All three main actors in the film are perfect and to be honest all deserve nominations for atleast one award in any ceremony. Jeff Bridges? A Legend. Chris Pine? Finally getting a chance to show his acting chops. Ben Foster? Whoa now, completely transformed himself (2016 has not been a bad year for him). What helped them was the script which had me transfixed from the first section of dialogue, it had everything from witty humour and banter between the characters to emotional tension between the brilliant brotherly bond (dare you to say that ten times in a row!) of Foster and Pine. The direction from David Mackenzie was solid and the cinematography was sublime with some really creative shots when following vehicles. Excellent wide shots to let the audience take in the Texan environment. I won't spoil the film, but there is a scene in the movie that is what I call an "Oh My God!" moment (a scene so shocking, I literally mouth those words out), did not see it coming whatsoever and I don't think anyone else did, brilliantly executed. The score was also appropriate, with country vibes that suit the Texas locale. I say it is close to perfection, the only flaw I found was that the script allows the characters to have too many conversations that do not further the plot. Whilst this is good for character development, too much of it and it starts to slow the pace down. Overall, Hell or High Water is a near perfect crime/drama with powerhouse performances (particularly Ben Foster) and a sublime script, even if the dialogue is bit excessive at times.

- Review at: http://www.themoviediorama.com

The very feel of the film embodies Texas: hot, slow, Cowboys and Indians. If you like loud, CG bank heists this is not the film for you. This has a far darker allegory behind it and the line between good and bad is unclear, as it is in life.
I could actually understand Jeff Bridges's thick texan accent in this one.

This film kind of ambles along, we're in the poor back waters of Texas, following two brothers (adeptly played by Ben Foster and Chris Pine) robbing small town banks, they're trying to raise enough cash to stop the same said bank foreclosing on the family property. It doesn't really crank up a gear until one heist goes wrong, when wiley Texas ranger (an ever so aged Jeff Bridges) is hot on their tails. Some good characterisation, even if the film only just about lifts off in the last third.

Good performances by Pine and Foster. Jeff Bridges is absolutely fantastic as a grizzly old Texas Ranger, a role that comes across very genuinely and endearingly on screen. He had much of the audience in the theater I was in chuckling often and we all seemed to genuinely enjoy the character he was portraying.
The opening scenes do a great job I think in establishing the dry small-town Texas atmosphere that will permeate throughout the movie.  The film really takes you to an interesting, if not exotic place in America.
Film reminds me very much of the morally ambiguous desperation of Bonnie and Clyde, this time in post-2008 recession times. 

The film moves thoughtfully and I think realistically through its story.  Thankfully, for my tastes, it substitutes gratuitous movie violence for a very believable realistic series of events. 
Hell or High Water will probably go down as one of the top 5 most critically acclaimed films of 2016.

And there is a FIRECRACKER ending that is just...stunning.
A good little film....recommended.

This film does play into some of the conventions of the crime-drama/heist-thriller genre (persons who try to stay one step ahead of the law and thumb their noses to the authorities, the lawman looking for one last case before he rides off into the sunset, etc.); that said, David Mackenzie and his production crew really push the envelope (for a movie of this genre) in an exciting way with regards to this film's cinematic elements, the visuals, and the execution. It takes about 10 minutes for the film's plot to kick in, but once it does, it's a manic ride from start to finish. The plot goes pretty deep, clawing at you with questions about our social landscape pitting the rich versus the "99%," what's (morally) right versus what is "just" for someone else's situation, and how loyal one could be to a loved one's cause. Almost all of the performances across the board in the flick are unanimously praiseworthy, in particular those of Chris Pine and Jeff Bridges. I have never been a big fan of Pine's work in the past, but I have to give him many props here for pleasantly shocking me with his role. Jeff Bridges is in fine form, as well (and hopefully, another potential Oscar nomination won't be ruled out). Ben Foster is a little over-the-top, but provides a nice counter balance to Chris Pine's calm, levelheaded characterization. It is definitely worth your time to check it out if you are interested at-all in seeing this movie, and comes with a high recommendation from myself. The flick is one of my favorites of the year (only behind another recent hit, "Captain Fantastic").

" A modern day western is the best way to describe "Hell or High Water". It has a small, personal feel to it, but the depth and richness of the film makes it more of an epic. Director David Mackenzie and Writer Taylor Sheridan ("Sicario") have developed a beautiful movie, from the scenery and setting, to the absolutely perfect script (It may be the most quotable film of the year)."

I couldn't rate this any high enough. The more time invested into this film, the more you come to understand each character's motivations. With this, you become emotionally attached with each side, wanting whoever to succeed and fail at the same time. This compared with a fitting soundtrack and beautiful direction in both framing and storytelling, I'll have to say this is already my favourite film of 2016 so far.
Or maybe I'm just biased because I loved Sicario but that was more thriller, this is more drama.

A films that mixes morals and highlights hypocrisy across all levels of society. A pair of brothers rob the banks that are foreclosing on their dead mother's farm in order to clear the debt. Using the vast open spaces of Texas as the backdrop, this plays out the small lives struggling to exist in a larger, cruel world. Excellent acting, well paced and not afraid to use long silences and lingering shots.
Best film I've seen in a theater since Ex Machina.

This is one of the best movies ever made, and I'm not saying that lightly or abusing hyperbole. One of the greatest films ever. It's a movie where the law breakers and the keepers are adversaries but not enemies. And it's so Texas, both hilariously and frighteningly so. This film has no pretenses. It is not trying to be anything more than what it is: clever, poignant, real.

The atmosphere in "Hell or High Water" was superb. It felt ripped straight out of current events and you could tell that a lot of effort went into encapsulating the plights of the working class in small town texas. I only wish this time and effort was applied to the writing as well. The characters felt hollow and i just found myself wanting it to be about the two side characters and their "grumpy old men' banter. Boy that would of been a good movie...

Essentially a cops and robbers thriller with a heavy tinge of the cowboy Western genre, it is also a political statement on poverty and a denouncement of our modern day financial banking system. While this will always be known as the film where Chris Pine shows us that he can do more than squint convincing as Captain Kirk and his is a nuanced and quietly powerful performance; there is also an immensely watchable Jeff Bridges who plays the tough Marshall in pursuit, and just because he can do the role in his sleep, we should not take him for granted. Scenes of his bantering with his deputy (played by Gil Birmingham) are funny, heart-warming/breaking and pay off towards the end of the film in an emotional and poignant fashion. Deliberately desolate and desperate yet peppered with astute observations of our times, the beautifully crafted film admittedly has a few wobbly or "posey" moments but in the end I found myself totally invested in a film that was written, directed and shot with a poetic and picturesque sentimentality that never boils over into hysterical melodrama.

This is not a bad film. It is certainly entertaining enough and well acted enough.
It is just not a terribly good film- I think average would be a better term. There is somewhat a lame attempt in  subplot to connect the awful wall street bailout with the working class poor living in Texas- willing to do anything to pay the mortgage- but let's face it- the brothers played by Chris Pine and Ben Foster would have probably robbed banks with or without the bailout- if they didn't- you wouldn't have a movie. If this film had been released in the '70s with a lower budget and a bunch of unknown actors- it would have been a fairly average drive in film-nothing more. You add the great Jeff Bridges to the mix and the sadly underused Gil Birmingham and you might have something. Of the two brothers Chris Pine gives a great performance as the moody younger brother. His performance is even keeled and convincing- especially in the last scene.  Ben Foster on the other hand, I did not feel was convincing at all. I have sadly known too many excons who have done 10+years in prison... and Ben Foster just did not have it down. He was too wild- too free with his movements.  People who have been locked up that long- do not wear it like a badge of honor. They generally are instutionalized and cagey and their movements are more measured and precise. They can instill fear without having to act all badass. They don't have to prove anything. I think this movie would have been better if PIne had played the moody excon and Foster had played the younger brother. Pine had it down and was more believable in his role and would have portrayed an excon more accurately. That being said- the movie is worth seeing for the last 15 minutes where Bridges demonstrates once again his versality and skill  as an actor- even playing the cliched wrinkled southern lawman. A better film with him in it would be 1992's American Heart- a much more powerful film with an even better performance. Compared to most of the crap released this summer- Hell of High Water soars.

Near the end, the Jeff Bridges character tells the Chris Pine character that he will be haunted by his actions.  So will we all.

Comancheria (or "Hell Over High Water"), is one of the best movies I have seen this year. The easiest way for me to describe it would be: "No Country for Old Men meets The Big Short"...

The acting in this movie is excellent. From the leads, to the supporting characters, everyone is fantastic. There is also great chemistry among the two main duos that are portrayed in this movie. The brothers, played by Chris Pine and Ben Foster, feel like they are actual brothers. They tease, they banter, they hoarse around, with the realism of real brothers. There relationship is well fleshed out, and our attachment to them grow as the movie progresses. The other amazing pair is Jeff Bridges and Gil Birmingham, as Texas Rangers. Their exchanges and interactions are captivating and fun to watch, which also makes the viewer grow more attached to them. While everyone performs well, special mention should be given to the Jeff Bridges. His presence and charisma were magnetic, and make every scene he was in twice as enjoyable.

The script is also excellent. It deals with themes that are rarely talked about, both in movies and in the news, but that has a devastating and sometimes deadly effect on people's lives: predatory loans and poverty. This movie treats these themes very cleverly, and brings into the spotlight issues that needs to be addressed. In addition to it's main themes, this movie also tackles other obscure topics few people speak of such as the savage treatment of the native Americans, or the less savage but still terrible treatment of war veterans. All these elements combine to deliver a story that draws you in and has you on the edge of your seat wondering what will happen next.

Finally, what would be a movie without great cinematography. The camera flows smoothly, making everything easy to follow, it offers some beautiful views of the New Mexican country side, it all just... works. There is no choppy editing, no shaky cam inferno, it's just perfect.

Conclusion: I could write for several paragraphs how amazing this movie is, but I'd rather forgo that and just tell you to GO SEE IT. This is a beautiful and powerful movie on a subject that is rarely touched upon, and performed by actors who draw you into story. This is a film that will no doubt receive Oscar nominations. If you appreciate good films, Comancheria is for you.
